data.title: Kenyan lady wins nobel peace prize
meta_keywords: newsKenyan lady  wins nobel peace prizeKenyan ecologist Wangari Maathai on Friday won the Nobel Peace Prize
data.meta_description: Kenyan ecologist Wangari Maathai on Friday won the Nobel Peace Prize
data.text:
OSLO, Friday - Kenyan ecologist Wangari Maathai on Friday won the Nobel Peace Prize, the first African woman to be awarded the prestigious prize since it was first handed out in 1901.

Maathai, who has served as Kenyan assistant minister for the environment since 2003, founded the Green Belt Movement in 1977, the largest tree planting project in Africa, aimed at promoting biodiversity and creating jobs and giving women a stronger identity in society.

The Nobel Committee honoured her â€œcontribution to sustainable development, democracy and peaceâ€.

â€œI am very delighted and I thank God for everything,â€ Maathai, joined in Nairobi, told AFP. â€œI will carry on with my campaign and I ask Kenyans to join me.

â€œI wonder who could have forwarded my name to the Nobel committee, but God knows,â€ she added.

Maathai said she had been informed earlier in the day by Norwayâ€™s ambassador to Kenya that she had won the coveted prize.

Maathai, 64, is a biologist by training. She was the first woman

in western Africa to receive a doctorate and become a professor. She is also an ardent human rights activist in Kenya.

She was elected to the Kenyan parliament on the Green Party ticket in December 2002 in the first free elections held in the country in decades. In January 2003, she was named assistant minister for the environment.

The Nobel Committee has for many years chosen to give the prize to people or organisations who have worked either to resolve conflicts by peaceful means or in defence of human rights.

But the Committee said in 2001, on the centenary of the Nobel prizes, that it planned to widen the scope of the award. Maathai is the first environmentalist to win the coveted prize, which comes with a US$1.3m package.

African Nobel prize winners

2003: Writer J.M. Coetzee wins the literature prize.

2001: Ghanaian-born UN Secretary General Kofi Annan is awarded the peace prize jointly with the world body â€œfor their work for a better organised and more peaceful worldâ€.

1993: Nobel Peace Prize is awarded jointly to South Africaâ€™s Nelson Mandela, a symbol of the countryâ€™s fight against the apartheid system, and then president Frederik de Klerk, â€œfor their work for the peaceful termination of the apartheid regime and for laying the foundations for a new democratic South Africaâ€.

1991: South Africaâ€™s Nadine Gordimer, whose work deals mainly with the racially driven tensions in her country, wins the literature prize.

1988: Novel and short story writer Naguib Mahfouz becomes the

first Egyptian to win the literature prize.

1986: Nigeriaâ€™s ethnic Yoruba playwright, poet and novelist Wole Soyinka wins the literature prize.

1984: South Africaâ€™s black Anglican Archbishop, Desmond Tutu, wins the peace prize for his role in the battle against the apartheid regime.

1978: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat shares the peace prize with Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin, who both signed the Camp David peace accords for the Middle East.

1960: Zulu chief Albert John Luthuli, head of South Africaâ€™s African National Congress - then a banned resistance movement - wins the peace prize for his fight against apartheid.

1951: South African Max Theiler wins the Nobel prize for medicine for developing a vaccine against yellow fever.
